awd_titl_txt: AGS-PRF The Effect of Particle Viscosity in the Reactive Uptake of Isoprene-derived Epoxides to Submicron Aerosols
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports a Postdoctoral Research Fellow to study the formation and growth of small particles in an environmental chamber.  There is significant interest in the formation of small particles in the atmosphere from volatile plant emissions such as isoprene.  Measurements in the laboratory will help to quantify the probability of such gas phase species forming aerosol mass in the atmosphere. 

A key approach for understanding the formation of secondary organic aerosols (SOAs) from isoprene is to study the uptake kinetics of epoxide species such as dihydroxyl epoxides (IEPOX) and methacrylic acid epoxide (MAE) on aerosol particles.  Chamber studies will be performed at varying relative humidity (RH) values to explore the effects of viscosity on reactive uptake.  This research will also examine the evolution of particle chemical composition as a function of viscosity both qualitatively and quantitatively through mass spectroscopic techniques.  Results obtained from this research will improve models used in climate studies, air quality assessment, epidemiology, and other areas of environmental health that can affect public policy related to climate change and public health.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we combined state-of-the-art techniques and models show that SOA coating can alter the reactive uptake of IEPOX onto acidic sulfate particles by more than one order of magnitude. We also show the importance of such processes in aerosol formation, air quality prediction, and climate change by further extending the scope and depth of this work. 

(1) Particulate matter (PM) has important climate and human health effects. Isoprene-derived SOA is one of the important sources of PM in many parts of the world. Studies have shown that isoprene-derived SOA can account for up to 40% of the total PM in the Southeast U.S. The likelihood of isoprene epoxydiols (IEPOX) reacting with ambient particles to form secondary organic aerosols (SOA) is derived in this study, which is defined as the reactive uptake coefficient (γIEPOX). γIEPOXis an important parameter for accurately modeling the amount of isoprene-derived SOA in the air and estimating these important effects of PM. In this study, γIEPOX for inorganic acidic sulfate particles is derived to be 2*10-2. 

However, ambient PM is complicated in composition and often does not exist in pure form. To solve this issue, this study also coated the inorganic acidic sulfate particles with atmosphere-relevant secondary organic materials that are derived from four types of common precursors. The γIEPOXvalues of particles with these organic coatings are then derived from these experiments. Figure 1 shows that even when the organic coating is 15 nm, γIEPOX could drop up to one order of magnitude. Our team is the first research group to conduct such study of IEPOX uptake with authentic SOA coatings, and we also work with the modeling team to implement the results into regional and global models to better simulate the effects of the organic coating on heterogeneous reactions. The results highlight the importance of organic coating on the formation of isoprene-derived SOA. 

(2) The phase state of the organic coating on top of these inorganic particles is the main reason for γIEPOX to change. Therefore, this study also derived the phase state of organic coatings at different relative humidity (RH) and composition. The multivariant and box models were used to derive a generalized relationship for better prediction of the isoprene-derived SOA in regional and global models. Figure 2 shows that as the most sensitive region to heterogeneous chemistry is when the viscosity of the SOA is in the range of 103 Pa s to 105 Pa s.  

(3) The chemical composition of the organic coatings and their effects on isoprene-derived SOA formation are also derived from this study. Figure 3 shows that as the O:C ratio of the SOA increases, the percent of IEPOX-derived SOA also increases because SOA becomes more hygroscopic and is easy for IEPOX to diffuse through. The current method provides a practical way to estimate the effects of aerosol phase states on SOA formation by using common instruments deployed in field campaigns, such as Aerosol Mass Spectrometer (AMS) or Aerosol Chemical Speciation Monitor (ACSM).

(4) This study also used the experimental results to explain field measurements and estimate the effects of SOA coating on isoprene-derived SOA in the Southeast U.S. To further understand the impacts of pre-existing SOA coatings on the reactive uptake of IEPOX, the ambient data collected from the 2013 SOAS campaign were used for model estimations. A comparison of IEPOX-derived SOA with and without an organic coating, together with diurnal RH variations based on field measurements made during the 2013 SOAS campaign at the Centerville, AL ground site is shown in Figure 4. The results show that IEPOX-derived SOA would have increased by 16-27% without considering the effect of pre-existing monoterpene SOA coatings during this time period. This result organically links the laboratory work with the field measurements and successfully proves that the results from laboratory studies are able to explain the phenomenon observed in the ambient environment. 

(5) The PI, Dr. Zhang, also collaborated with Professor Daniel Cziczo from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to study the effects of aerosol phase state on SOA formation. Figure 5 show that changing of phase state acts as a ?switch? between the inability to form ice (liquid-like) and the ability to act as an ice nucleation particles (INP), greatly enhancing the ice nucleation properties of certain organic aerosols. The findings have important implications in estimating the radiative balance of clouds and global climate change.

(6) The PI, Dr. Zhang, also worked with Boston College and Aerodyne Research to measure the phase state and glass transition temperatures of common organic aerosols including those found in isoprene-derived SOA with the support of this grant and others. Figure 6 are used to improve understandings both in fundamental physical chemistry as well as in estimating organic aerosol formation in atmospheric chemistry.
